an10.89:1.1: Then the mendicant Kokālika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
an10.89:1.2: “Sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”
an10.89:1.3: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!
an10.89:1.4: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
an10.89:2.1: For a second time Kokālika said to the Buddha,
an10.89:2.2: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”
an10.89:2.3: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!
an10.89:2.4: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
an10.89:3.1: For a third time Kokālika said to the Buddha,
an10.89:3.2: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”
an10.89:3.3: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!
an10.89:3.4: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
an10.89:4.1: Then Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
an10.89:4.2: Not long after he left his body erupted with boils the size of mustard seeds.
an10.89:4.3: The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood-apples, then ripe wood-apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out.
an10.89:4.4: He just laid down on banana leaves like a poisoned fish.
an10.89:5.1: Then Tudu the independent divinity went to Kokālika, and standing in the air he said to him,
an10.89:5.2: “Kokālika, have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
an10.89:5.6: “Didn’t the Buddha declare you a non-returner? So what then are you doing back here?
an10.89:5.7: See how far you have strayed!”
an10.89:6.1: Then Tudu addressed Kokālika in verse:
an10.89:7.2: with an axe in their mouth.
an10.89:7.3: A fool cuts themselves with it
an10.89:8.1: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,
an10.89:8.2: or criticize someone worthy of praise,
an10.89:8.3: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:
an10.89:8.4: you’ll never find happiness that way.
an10.89:9.1: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,
an10.89:9.2: if all you lose is your money
an10.89:9.3: and all you own, even yourself.
an10.89:9.5: is to hate the holy ones.
an10.89:10.1: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million
an10.89:10.2: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years
an10.89:10.3: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,
an10.89:10.4: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”
an10.89:11.1: Then the mendicant Kokālika died of that illness.
an10.89:11.2: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
an10.89:12.1: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sahampati, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
an10.89:12.2: “Sir, the mendicant Kokālika has passed away.
an10.89:12.3: He was reborn in the pink lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
an10.89:12.4: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.
an10.89:12.5: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
an10.89:13.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
an10.89:14.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
an10.89:14.2: “Sir, how long is the lifespan in the Pink Lotus hell?”
an10.89:14.5: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
an10.89:15.1: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”
an10.89:15.3: “Suppose there was a Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.
an10.89:15.4: By this means the Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell.
an10.89:15.5: Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell.
an10.89:15.6: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.
an10.89:15.7: Twenty lifetimes in the Ababa hell equal one lifetime in the Aṭaṭa hell.
an10.89:15.8: Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell.
an10.89:15.9: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.
an10.89:15.10: Twenty lifetimes in the Yellow Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Fragrant Water Lily hell.
an10.89:15.11: Twenty lifetimes in the Fragrant Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the Blue Water Lily hell.
an10.89:15.12: Twenty lifetimes in the Blue Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the White Lotus hell.
an10.89:15.13: Twenty lifetimes in the White Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Pink Lotus hell.
an10.89:15.14: The mendicant Kokālika has been reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
an10.89:15.15: That is what the Buddha said.
an10.89:15.16: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
